data.text: @HuffmanLabDU @ssprd (Satire) Why would you still measure air?? cAseS aRe DoWn! https://t.co/iiOsfedW4H

@DocJeffD @HuffmanLabDU @ssprd Kraken games are covid free. 

Crimes against children unmask children now https://t.co/0vEZMU5wcY

@HuffmanLabDU @ssprd My experience, from working meets for eight years or so while one of my daughters was a competitive swimmer, is that pool IEQ at the HS level is pretty awful on average. Ventilation rate per occupant may not be the controlling factor.

https://t.co/x3EWFBhF4v

@DocJeffD @HuffmanLabDU @ssprd Indoor pools need great ventilation to avoid the creation of trichloramines near the water surface.  Very caustic and close to tear gas in composition. Without fresh air and substantial air turnover, you run the risk of trichloramine production.
@HuffmanLabDU @ssprd I found the same where I swim.  I think pools are relatively well-ventilated to purge chlorine (or other disinfectant) vapor.

@gf_traveller @ssprd Also really important to say that community COVID rates are central to these decision. Also, personal & family dynamics are critical. We want to give our oldest agency to decide, bc she’s growing & headstrong. Likely will keep mask, but needs the option to choose for herself.

@gf_traveller @ssprd Our district dropped mandate wks ago, but our 3 kids kept masking. Oldest eats lunch in a smaller room w/ few people & HEPA filter. This week our family policy goes to  “mask optional” bc oldest really annoyed at the rule. Sounds like she’ll mostly keep on anyway. BUT …
@ee_kelsey @ssprd Yes. I’m not a ventilation expert, but I’m confident they had a high ventilation rate with outdoor air, given the pool facility.
